question: I'm worried I've got COVID. Is there a covid screening station in Taichung where I can get a free COVID-19 test?
answer: 6/25 UPDATE several health facilities have set up outdoors COVID-19 Fast Screening Stations to provide rapid antigen testing for free if you have an official address in Taichung.  Bring ID cards (ARC, APRC, VISA), health insurance cards (NHIC), and wear medical masks throughout the journey. Most locations require you to make an online appointment and ask to come early. Check our map for more details and help with navigation. Screening services will be suspended if they run out of tests If the test result is negative, you will be notified on the spot, and no paper report will be provided (result can be checked in your health passbook 1-3 days after) Those who test positive will be transferred to the emergency room for follow-up
markdownAnswer:
**6/25** several **health facilities have set up outdoors COVID-19 Fast Screening Stations** to provide rapid antigen testing for free if you have an official address in Taichung.
- Bring ID cards (ARC, APRC, VISA), health insurance cards (NHIC), and wear medical masks throughout the journey.
- Most locations require you to make an online appointment and ask to come early. Check [our map](https://www.covid-taichung.com/maps/) for more details and help with navigation.
- Screening services will be suspended if they run out of tests
- If the test result is negative, you will be notified on the spot, and no paper report will be provided (result can be checked in your health passbook 1-3 days after)
- Those who test positive will be transferred to the emergency room for follow-up

question: What epidemic alert level is Taiwan in currently? What are the guidelines and rules for Taichung at this moment? What's the COVID-level 3 timeline or end date?
answer: On Tuesday 7/27, Taiwan changes from national alert level 3 to level 2. From articles from CDC (English) and Taichung city government (Chinese), we can confirm 3 major changes:  Gathering restrictions change to maximum 100 people (including you) outdoors, and 50 people (including you) indoors. Indoor dining allowed at restaurants that implement crowd control and staff management measures such as mask wearing, temperature checks, 1922 tracking system, and social distancing. Cram schools may reopen upon approval from MOE and under strict rules. Those include regular PCR tests for teachers who haven't been vaccinated for at least 14 days, double-masking (full face shield cover and mouth mask), and a fixed seating plan for each classroom. Talk to your school for more details. 7/14 Taichung city government posted an update about venues that may open:  Public sports venues can open outdoor playgrounds and trails. Private sports venues such as gyms depends so check first. Park roads and public toilets may open but sports facilities, pavilions, playgrounds, basketball courts, etc. remain closed. Night markets may resume business but eating and drinking are prohibited. Movie theaters with masks, temperature checks, 1922 tracking system, no eating and drinking, social distancing. Exhibition spaces of cultural centers and museums are open to visit by appointment Outdoor playgrounds of municipal schools according to normal weekday opening hours during the semester. Toilets, playgrounds, sports fields remain closed. The outdoor plaza and parking lot of the Dongshi Hakka Park and Shigang Tuniu Hakka Cultural Hall 7/11 Taichung city government has decided which restrictions will be loosened. Most remain the same but some tourist spots will reopen in Taichung from 7/13 (but platforms, physical fitness facilities, children's recreational facilities, and pavilions remain closed): Dakeng hiking trails No. 1 to 8, Tanzi Xintian trail, Dadu hiking trails, Wuri Zhi Gao Zhun walking trail, Cheng Gong trails, Rainbow Village Hongfeng Bicycle Green Way, Hou-Fong bike path, Tanya Shen Green Bikeway Dajia Tiezhenshan Scenic Area Walkways at the Daan Mazu Gaomei Coastal area (beaches remain closed) Tourist sites that remain closed in Taichung until 7/26:  Dakeng hiking trails No. 9 to 10 and Guguan Hot Spring Travel Service Centers at public transport stations, airports and tourist sites 7/8 CDC has extended alert level 3 to July 26, 2021. Local governments may loosen some restrictions starting 7/13.  6/24 CDC has extended the Nationwide Level 3 epidemic alert 3 to July 12, 2021.  6/10 CDC listed regulations and guidelines in English. A quick summary:  Obligated/Fined: Always wear masks outdoors. Those with symptoms should seek medical attention. Supermarkets, stores, and businesses must implement crowd control measures.  Closed/Banned: All parks, night markets, playgrounds, schools & daycare, community services & workshops, sports venues, libraries, tourist sites, leisure & entertainment venues, weddings & memorials, places of worship are closed. No more than 9 people (including you) may gather outdoors, and no more than 4 people (including you) indoors, those living together not included. As soon as you have 1 visitor in your family home who has a different official address, the rule of maximum 4 applies.   Advised: Social distancing, reduce shopping frequency, distance working, flexible hours, avoid all non-essential travel to all countries.  Others: Food & beverage vendors only takeout. Enhanced disinfection of public places and public transport, details on our maps page.
markdownAnswer: **On Tuesday 7/27, Taiwan changes from national alert level 3 to level 2**. From [articles from CDC](https://www.cdc.gov.tw/En/Bulletin/Detail/C-9A7siqyLWsca5Qb6npkA?typeid=158) and [Taichung city government](https://www.taichung.gov.tw/1174224/1174227/1174251/), we can confirm 3 major changes: - Gathering restrictions change to maximum **100 people (including you) outdoors, and 50 people (including you) indoors.** - **Indoor dining allowed** at restaurants that implement crowd control and staff management measures such as mask wearing, temperature checks, 1922 tracking system, and social distancing. - **Cram schools may reopen** upon approval from MOE and under strict rules. Those include regular PCR tests for teachers who haven't been vaccinated for at least 14 days, double-masking (full face shield cover and mouth mask), and a fixed seating plan for each classroom. Talk to your school for more details. **7/14** Taichung city government posted an [update about venues that may open](https://www.taichung.gov.tw/1822741/post): - Public sports venues can open outdoor playgrounds and trails. Private sports venues such as gyms depends so check first. - Park roads and public toilets may open but sports facilities, pavilions, playgrounds, basketball courts, etc. remain closed. - Night markets may resume business but eating and drinking are prohibited. - Movie theaters with masks, temperature checks, 1922 tracking system, no eating and drinking, social distancing. - Exhibition spaces of cultural centers and museums are open to visit by appointment - Outdoor playgrounds of municipal schools according to normal weekday opening hours during the semester. Toilets, playgrounds, sports fields remain closed. - The outdoor plaza and parking lot of the Dongshi Hakka Park and Shigang Tuniu Hakka Cultural Hall **7/11** Taichung city government has decided which restrictions will be loosened. Most remain the same but **[some tourist spots](https://www.covid-taichung.com/frequently-asked-questions/#)** will reopen in Taichung from **7/13** (but platforms, physical fitness facilities, children's recreational facilities, and pavilions remain closed): - Dakeng hiking trails No. 1 to 8, Tanzi Xintian trail, Dadu hiking trails, Wuri Zhi Gao Zhun walking trail, Cheng Gong trails, Rainbow Village - Hongfeng Bicycle Green Way, Hou-Fong bike path, Tanya Shen Green Bikeway - Dajia Tiezhenshan Scenic Area - Walkways at the Daan Mazu Gaomei Coastal area (beaches remain closed) Tourist sites that **remain closed in Taichung until 7/26**: - Dakeng hiking trails No. 9 to 10 and Guguan Hot Spring - Travel Service Centers at public transport stations, airports and tourist sites **7/8** CDC has [extended alert level 3 to July 26, 2021](https://www.cdc.gov.tw/En/Bulletin/Detail/vlmAORqyqEntz1Tr_Ls7DQ?typeid=158). Local governments may loosen some restrictions starting 7/13. 6/24 CDC has extended the [Nationwide Level 3 epidemic alert 3 to July 12, 2021](https://www.cdc.gov.tw/En/Bulletin/Detail/en36fygNXciYYgmgcWPHuQ?typeid=158). 6/10 CDC listed [regulations and guidelines in English](https://www.cdc.gov.tw/En/Bulletin/Detail/uIsfZpLbzqQ_uBK71xZ8Xg?typeid=158). A quick summary: **Obligated/Fined**: Always wear masks outdoors. Those with symptoms should seek medical attention. Supermarkets, stores, and businesses must implement crowd control measures. **Closed/Banned**: All parks, night markets, playgrounds, schools & daycare, community services & workshops, sports venues, libraries, tourist sites, leisure & entertainment venues, weddings & memorials, places of worship are closed. No more than 9 people (including you) may gather outdoors, and no more than 4 people (including you) indoors, those living together not included. As soon as you have 1 visitor in your family home who has a different official address, the rule of maximum 4 applies. **Advised**: Social distancing, reduce shopping frequency, distance working, flexible hours, avoid all non-essential travel to all countries. **Others**: Food & beverage vendors only takeout. [Enhanced disinfection of public places and public transport, details on our maps page](https://www.covid-taichung.com/maps/).

question: When can I get a vaccine in Taiwan? Am I eligible? What are the priorities for vaccination? How can I register for my first dose of Moderna or Astra Zeneca?
answer: Vaccination locations and information change almost daily. We've added the main health facilities in Taichung that provide English services to our covid map and update as we go.   7/8 It has been confirmed that anyone in Taiwan aged 18-64 with medical conditions (details below) as well as anyone older than 50 can now make a reservation here. You will be put on a waiting list and receive a text (SMS) message with further instructions in the coming weeks.  Click the button [Register] (登記) at the bottom of the blue section. On the next page enter both numbers on your NHCI (National Health Insurance Card).  Type the verification code and click the button [Verification] (執行身分認證). If you have a new ARC number (BXXXXXXXXX) and you receive an error, try again with your old number (BCXXXXXXXX) or vice versa. If you are in a priority group because of your job, your employer will inform you. This summary applies to individuals and is updated regularly based on feedback from Taichung health centers:  Those required to travel abroad under special circumstances  All people older than 50 years (50-69 on waitlist, +70 has priority) Pregnant women (talk to your physician as there are special clinics available) Adults ages 18-49 with high-risk diseases, rare diseases, or serious medical conditions (talk to your physician) 6/2 the Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) first listed 10 priority groups.
markdownAnswer: Vaccination locations and information change almost daily. We've added the main health facilities in Taichung that provide English services to [our covid map](https://www.covid-taichung.com/maps/) and update as we go. **7/13** Anyone older than 18 can now register their "willingness to get vaccinated". We wrote a [separate FAQ about this with detailed instructions](https://www.covid-taichung.com/frequently-asked-questions/#question26). **7/11** For those in groups 9 and 10 that have registered, [text messages will be sent out from 7/13](https://www.cdc.gov.tw/Bulletin/Detail/LFEwMGAQQaE-q0wQ6ioHkQ?typeid=9) and vaccinations will start 7/16. CDC adds that the next 3 weeks will be Astra Zeneca. **7/8** It has been confirmed that anyone in Taiwan aged 18-64 with medical conditions (details below) as well as anyone older than 50 can [make a reservation here](https://1922.gov.tw/vas/) (closed on 7/12 17:00). You will be put on a waiting list and receive a text (SMS) message with further instructions in the coming weeks. - Click the button [Register] (登記) at the bottom of the blue section. On the next page enter both numbers on your NHIC (National Health Insurance Card). - Type the verification code and click the button [Verification] (執行身分認證). If you have a new ARC number (BXXXXXXXXX) and you receive an error, try again with your old number (BCXXXXXXXX) or vice versa. If you are in a priority group because of your job, your employer will inform you. This summary applies to individuals that can book vaccination now and is updated regularly based on feedback from Taichung health centers: - Those required to travel abroad under special circumstances - All people older than 50 years (50-69 on waitlist, +70 has priority) - Pregnant women (talk to your physician) - Adults ages 18-64 with [high-risk diseases](https://reurl.cc/Nr2E36), [rare diseases](https://reurl.cc/R02Qx6), or serious medical conditions (talk to your physician) **6/2** the Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) first listed [10 priority groups](https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/4214853).

question: What are some important phone numbers with regard to the current outbreak in Taiwan? Who should I call for English assistance with covid-related questions and concerns?
answer: Please note that it depends on your device and browser if and how the links for the phone numbers below will be opened after you click on them. And this will only work for local calls in Taiwan. 1922 is the 24 hours/toll-free hotline from Taiwan CDC for service on disease reporting, communicable disease consultation, prevention policy promotion and control measure education to the public 119 is the 24 hours/toll-free emergency number for Ambulances and Fire Alarms 110 is the 24 hours/toll-free emergency number for Police Services 0800-024-111, press [2] for English service on the 24 hours/toll-free International Community Service Hotline 0800-011-765 is the English-speaking/24 hours/toll-free Travel Information Call Center 106 is the number for Directory Enquiries (English-speaking) 1925 is the 24-hour/toll-free care hotline of the Ministry of Health and Welfare (MOFW) for mental health consulting 1955 is the 24 hours/toll-free hotline of the Ministry of Labor (MOL) for labor counseling to help migrant workers with communication and adaptation to the Taiwanese lifestyle. It also offers an online interpretation service in Chinese, Indonesian, Vietnamese, Thai and Filipino to solve communication problems between employers and migrant workers.
markdownAnswer:
Please note that it depends on your device and browser if and how the links for the phone numbers below will be opened after you click on them. And this will only work for local calls in Taiwan.
- [1922](tel:1922) is the 24 hours/toll-free hotline from Taiwan CDC for service on **disease reporting, communicable disease consultation, prevention policy promotion and control measure education** to the public
- [119](tel:119) is the 24 hours/toll-free **emergency number for Ambulances and Fire Alarms**
- [110](tel:110) is the 24 hours/toll-free **emergency number for Police Services**
- [0800-024-111](tel:0800024111), press [2] for English service on the 24 hours/toll-free **International Community Service Hotline**
- [0800-011-765](tel:0800011765) is the English-speaking/24 hours/toll-free **Travel Information Call Center**
- [106](tel:106) is the number for **Directory Enquiries** (English-speaking)
- [1925](1925) is the 24-hour/toll-free care hotline of the Ministry of Health and Welfare (MOFW) for **mental health consulting**
- [1955](1955) is the 24 hours/toll-free hotline of the Ministry of Labor (MOL) for **labor counseling to help migrant workers** with communication and adaptation to the Taiwanese lifestyle. It also offers an **online interpretation service in Chinese, Indonesian, Vietnamese, Thai and Filipino** to solve communication problems between employers and migrant workers.

question: What to do if your residence (ARC, APRC) or staying permit (VISA) is about to expire?
answer: ARC or APRC alien residency certificate holders:  Automatically extended with 30 days with no upper limit on the number of extensions. Extend your leave of stay at a service station no later than 30 days after the pandemic alert has been lowered to level 2 alert. VISA as tourist or student or originally had permission to delay departure from Taiwan:  Do not have to extend leave or stay or delay departure for the time being Extend your leave of stay at a service station no later than 10 days after the pandemic alert has been lowered to level 2 alert.
markdownAnswer:
A summary of this [article](https://www.immigration.gov.tw/5475/5478/141457/141990/264991/) for your convenience:

**ARC or APRC** alien residency certificate holders:
- Automatically extended with 30 days with no upper limit on the number of extensions.
- Extend your leave of stay at a service station no later than 30 days after the pandemic alert has been lowered to level 2 alert.

*VISA holders* (working, student, tourist) or originally had permission to delay departure from Taiwan:
- Do not have to extend leave or stay or delay departure for the time being.
- Extend your leave of stay at a service station no later than 10 days after the pandemic alert has been lowered to level 2 alert.

question: Where can I get a Covid self-test kit? How to use the coronavirus testing kit at home?
answer: 7/11 CDC posted a YouTube video with English audio and subtitles: Instructions for the use of COVID 19 home test kits  COVID-19 rapid antigen self-test kits can be purchased at drug stores, pharmacies, medical equipment shops, and convenience stores.  Check for FDA-approved tests (click links that end with Chinese date eg 110.7.1). Follow the instructions to collect a sample and administer the test. When the result is negative, place the kit in a sealed plastic bag and dispose in the household garbage. When the result is positive, immediately call the toll-free hotline 1922 and go into home quarantine (separate rooms including bathroom, always mask). If you're unable to go into home isolation, put the test kit in sealed plastic bag, visit a nearby clinic or hospital asap and hand it to the staff, wear a mask at all times, and do not use public transport
markdownAnswer:

question: How do I register and book for the COVID vaccination process? How to use the website 1922.gov.tw to apply to get vaccinated?
answer: Everyone older than 18 can begin registration from 7/13 12:00 on 1922.gov.tw. CDC open and close the site according to availability and priority groups. Check or download our step-by-step guide or read on for basic instructions:  - Once you get to page 2 you have 10 minutes to complete the process so have your National Health Insurance card and Chinese address ready before you begin - Translation services don't work on all the buttons and some reported that the software or plugin stopped or restarted the process - Page 1: Browse to 1922.gov.tw/vas and click the button [Register] 登記 in the blue box.  - Page 2: Enter the ARC/APRC and NHI number that are on your NHI card. Then enter the confirmation code and click the button at the bottom. - Page 3: Check your info and add your phone (only numbers 09XXXXXXX). Then select your county and district, select preferred vaccine type(s), and accept terms and conditions. - Page 4: This page confirms your date and time of registration and shows a registration ID. We recommend taking a screenshot then you can close the page.  This is only a registration of your willingness to get vaccinated. Now you have to wait for a text (SMS) message from 1922 with further instructions in the coming days.
